channel.title: Recent Activity from People You Follow

item.title: Recent Activity from Werner Vogels, Purnima
item.description:
Werner Vogels turned on Public Notes for
The Back of the Napkin: Solving Problems and Selling Ideas with Pictures by Dan Roam, What's Next?: Dispatches on the Future of Science by Max Brockman, Trust Me: Four Steps to Authenticity and Charisma by Nick Morgan, The Lombardi Rules by Vince Lombardi, Here Comes Everybody: The Power of Organizing Without Organizations by Clay Shirky, The Future of the Internet--And How to Stop It by Jonathan Zittrain, The Fourth Paradigm: Data-Intensive Scientific Discovery by Tony Hey, Stewart Tansley, Kristin Tolle, The Essence of Chaos by Edward N. Lorenz, Dynamic Modeling by Bruce Hannon, Matthias Ruth, Cognitive Surplus: Creativity and Generosity in a Connected Age by Clay Shirky, Citizen Engineer: A Handbook for Socially Responsible Engineering by David Douglas, Greg Papadopoulos, John Boutelle, The Box: How the Shipping Container Made the World Smaller and the World Economy Bigger by Marc Levinson, The 4-Hour Body: An Uncommon Guide to Rapid Fat-Loss, Incredible Sex, and Becoming Superhuman by Timothy Ferriss

Purnima finished reading Autobiography of a Yogi (Reprint of Original 1946 Edition) by Paramhansa Yogananda, Powers Within by Sri Aurobindo, The Mother

Werner Vogels turned off Public Notes for The Lombardi Rules by Vince Lombardi

Purnima hopes to read Gitanjali by Rabindranath Tagore

item.title: Recent Activity from Tom Killalea
item.description:
Tom Killalea shared from The Tower, The Zoo, and The Tortoise: A Novel by Julia Stuart
"“What I can’t forgive is that he’s never even cried.” The old man looked at her. “We might love each other in the same way,” he said, “but it doesn’t mean that we grieve in the same way.”"
Note: The Tower, The Zoo, and The Tortoise. People need to grieve in their own way.

item.title: Recent Activity from Tom Killalea
item.description:
Tom Killalea shared from LETTER FROM CAIRO | The Contenders in the Reporting & Essays section of The New Yorker by Joshua Hammer
"“If a huge number of people call for change, the government will have to react,” ElBaradei said. “If you want to avoid uprisings, or demonstrations, you need to respond to the people’s desperate need for change.” He told me about one sign of popular desire: a Facebook page supporting his candidacy. “There are sixty thousand people in this Facebook group, and it’s growing,” he said. (As of last week, there were seventy-six thousand.) “They never even consulted me about establishing this Facebook thing. I had no clue.” ♦"
Note: The New Yorker and ElBaradei in April 2010 on change in #Egypt

item.title: Recent Activity from Tom Killalea
item.description:

"“If a huge number of people call for change, the government will have to react,” ElBaradei said. “If you want to avoid uprisings, or demonstrations, you need to respond to the people’s desperate need for change.” He told me about one sign of popular desire: a Facebook page supporting his candidacy. “There are sixty thousand people in this Facebook group, and it’s growing,” he said. (As of last week, there were seventy-six thousand.) “They never even consulted me about establishing this Facebook thing. I had no clue.” ♦"
Note: The New Yorker and ElBaradi in April 2010 on change in #Egypt

item.title: Recent Activity from Tom Killalea
item.description:
Tom Killalea shared from All Marketers are Liars (with a New Preface): The Underground Classic That Explains How Marketing Really Works--and Why Authenticity Is the Best Marketing of All by Seth Godin
"“What’s your story?” “Will the people who need to hear this story believe it?” “Is it true?”"
Note: Public Notes show 3 questions Seth Godin asks people struggling with a project http://bit.ly/emUbx9

item.title: Recent Activity from Janna, Tom Killalea
item.description:
Janna started reading Shadowfever by Karen Marie Moning, A Clash of Kings by George R.R. Martin

Tom Killalea shared from Insubordinate by Seth Godin
"Apparent risk is different from actual risk. Apparent risk is the fear in your gut when you launch stuff quickly, challenge the status quo, play with packaging or pricing or distribution, and do it with abandon. It’s not actual risk, because in a fast-moving market, the risky thing to do is to play it safe."
Note: @ThisIsSethsBlog on apparent risk v. actual risk in product development.

Tom Killalea finished reading Brains: How They Seem to Work by Dale Purves, Proust and the Squid: The Story and Science of the Reading Brain by Maryanne Wolf, Catherine J. Stoodley
